conclusion: To calculate the distance traveled by the car within 60 seconds, we need to analyze the acceleration-time graph and determine the velocity and position of the car at different time intervals.

The graph shows the acceleration a of the car over time t. The acceleration changes in two intervals: From t = 0 to t = 30 seconds, the acceleration is a = 2 m/s^2. From t = 30 to t = 60 seconds, the acceleration is a = -1 m/s^2.

premise: Initial velocity v_0 = 0 (since the car starts from rest).
conclusion: The velocity v can be found by integrating the acceleration with respect to time.

premise: Initial velocity at t = 30 seconds is v(30) = 60 m/s.

conclusion: The position x can be found by integrating the velocity with respect to time.

premise: x(t) = x_0 + ∫0^t v(t) dt, x(t) = 0 + ∫0^t 2t dt
Initial position at t = 30 seconds is x(30) = 900 m.
